Retirement Fever
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Washington is not the only place where people are getting fed up. 

  EISNER STEPS DOWN -- Michael Eisner, the chairman of Disney, resigned today, saying he felt he could "no longer make a difference" in the entertainment industry. He joins the swelling ranks of disaffected movie executives who have opted for early retirement. In a news conference, he expressed frustration with the "sour mood" in Hollywood and the "fickleness" of movie audiences. "It's been very hard not only on me but on my family," he said. He also criticized the entertainment industry's preoccupation with making a profit.

nytimes_articles.abstract:

SOAPBOX;Watch Out for Mr. $22.05
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Robert Lipsyte's Coping column of Jan. 21, about a Manhattan con man, and his sequel last Sunday have attracted an extraordinary response. Dozens of New Yorkers have called or written to report their own encounters with a neatly dressed young black man with red hair and freckles who seems, somehow, to know them -- drawing the information out of them that he needs. Others wrote of similar cons. While there is not space for all of those tales, here is one with  a twist. 

      ON a springish night in 1993, I was walking down the Avenue of the Americas  with my girlfriend, Nancy. Reaching the corner of 51st, I saw a Hasidic man, in  full but disheveled garb, with wounded and just-about-to-tear eyes, above a scratch or two on a forlorn face.

Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Once Upon a Time in the Northwest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hollywood is sure to ruin SHOOT! (St. Martin's, $22.95), an absorbing, panoramic novel set in the waning Wild West days of British Columbia. It's that  good: intricately plotted, meticulously researched and shaded with nuance. In "Shoot!" the Canadian poet and novelist George Bowering tells the story of four  young men whose Indian mothers and white fathers earn them the dismissive status of half-breeds. Caught between two cultures that neither understand nor accept them, the boys tumble self-destructively from petty thievery to murder. With page after page of thundering hoofbeats, shoot-outs and blood-red sunsets, Shoot! does the western genre proud. But what truly distinguishes this novel is  Mr. Bowering's unflinching examination of bigotry and intolerance, which seems as relevant to today's world as to that of the 1870's. Steady doses of wit and adventure help his brusque prose recover from occasional didactic detours, and a spiraling narrative structure gives the old-fashioned setting some post-modern flair. If nothing else, discovering the source of its deceptively hee-haw title  is reason enough to tempt plenty of curious readers.   Liam Callahan

Company Buys High-Rise Complex
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Robert Martin Company, Westchester's largest commercial property owner, based here, which spent two years divesting itself of some of its so-called non-core properties, now owns one of the tallest office buildings between New York City and Albany. 

     Robert Martin and the Hong Kong real-estate investment company Glorious Sun bought Blue Hill Plaza, a 1.2-million-square-foot high-rise complex in Pearl River in Rockland County for $45 million, officials close to the transaction reported. The closing took place Jan. 19.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gay Editor's Transfer Rests on a Lie
Beethoven Back, Wit' Bells, Smoke, Lights and Whistles
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FRESH from lunch and full of a "down-home country feeling and shiitake mushrooms," as he put it, David Alan Miller, music director of the Albany Symphony Orchestra and a finalist for the position of music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, was both live on the wire from his home in Albany and a very live wire himself. 

     Doing a telephone re-enactment of his impression of Beethoven, whom he will be personifying next Sunday at Tilles Center, Mr. Miller, whose highly animated  conversational style occasionally stretched the limits of fiber optics, lapsed into a stagey German accent reminiscent of Professor Ludwig von Drake, Donald Duck's purported Teutonic cousin.

Ray McIntire, 77, Dow Engineer And the Inventor Of Styrofoam
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Ray McIntire, a former chemical engineer for the Dow Chemical Company who invented by accident the material now known as Styrofoam, died on Friday at his  home in Midland, Mich. He was 77. 

     Mr. McIntire had suffered from interstitial fibrosis, a lung disease, which made it difficult for him to breathe, said his wife, Elizabeth McIntire.

nytimes_articles.headline: Vatican Says Sudan Forced Priest to Confess to Bomb Plot
SOAPBOX: Maestro, and More;Remembering Henry Lewis, Alight With Intensity
nytimes_articles.abstract:
I AM known as a basso profundo, but Henry Lewis made me feel like a tenor. He had one of the deepest and most impressive speaking voices of anyone I have ever met. But everything about him was impressive: his intense, charismatic personality, his boundless energy and his superior musical talent. 

     Henry Lewis is remembered as the first black music director of a major orchestra, but that label grossly understates his accomplishment. The New Jersey Symphony was a fine but little-known entity outside the state until Mr. Lewis took it over in 1968. Obviously, it was not his ethnic heritage but his talent and exacting leadership that raised the orchestra to prominence.

JERSEY;Fish Rights: The Final Frontier
Having Gotten the Part, Bronfman Plays the Mogul
On Cape Verde, Carnival Is Down to Earth
nytimes_articles.abstract:
COME Carnival time, news broadcasts around the globe show a whirl of crowds and floats and bikinis and beads. But only on the local news in the Cape Verde Islands can one see pictures of little boys covered in mud. There have never been enough policemen to keep order at Carnival, so crowd control is left to mud boys who sprint along the sidelines, smearing anyone who gets in the way of the  parade. 

     Celebrations of the days leading up to Ash Wednesday and the beginning of Lent in this long-forgotten place some 300 miles off the coast of Senegal may not be as glamorous as the spectacles of Rio and New Orleans, but they are certainly earthier, a memorable expression of a centuries-old culture.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLASSICAL MUSIC;And Now, Some Spanish Music From, of All Places, Spain
Man of the House
Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Intimate Expressionism
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the appropriately titled essay "A Long View" in HOWARD HODGKIN PAINTINGS (Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth/Abrams, $39.95), Michael Auping, the chief curator at the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, traces the development of Mr. Hodgkin's career, asserting that the English artist's earliest work established  the essential elements that have preoccupied him for some 40 years -- the representation of figures in an interior space and the depiction of memory, for example. A brilliant colorist whose work is often seen as falling somewhere  between representation and abstraction, Mr. Hodgkin "does not allow illustration to interfere with the making of a painting," Mr. Auping writes. "Memory and metaphor are his preferred terrain." Mr. Auping finds that Mr. Hodgkin's paintings of the last two decades have forged the unlikely pairing of Intimism and Expressionism from wildly diverse influences like Henri Matisse, douard Vuillard, Barnett Newman, Jackson Pollock, Jasper Johns and Willem de Kooning. Or as the cultural critic Susan Sontag puts it in her illuminating meditation: "Hodgkin has understood that if the pictures are dense enough, they can go in two directions, doing justice to intimate textures as well as to emotions of a large expressiveness. (Both Vuillard and opera, so to speak.)" Along with 80 color illustrations are an erudite and informative epistolary exchange between Mr. Hodgkin and John Elderfield, the chief curator at large at the Museum of Modern Art, and the first catalogue raisonn of Mr. Hodgkin's oil paintings, compiled by Marla Price, the director of the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth.   Robin Lippincott

nytimes_articles.abstract:
COME Carnival time, news broadcasts around the globe show a whirl of crowds and floats and bikinis and beads. But only on the local news in the Cape Verde Islands can one see pictures of little boys covered in mud. There have never been enough policemen to keep order at Carnival, so crowd control is left to mud boys who sprint along the sidelines, smearing anyone who gets in the way of the  parade. 

     Celebrations of the days leading up to Ash Wednesday and the beginning of Lent in this long-forgotten place some 300 miles off the coast of Senegal may not be as glamorous as the spectacles of Rio and New Orleans, but they are certainly earthier, a memorable expression of a centuries-old culture.

Neighborhood Report;The House of David, Digitized
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Rabbi Naftali Halberstam rushed into the production room, his shoulder-to-heel satin coat trailing slightly, and after suddenly stopping, he swung around to face his guests as any museum curator might do when showing off  his most prized piece. 

     "This," he said, with seven tall stacks of paper behind him, "this is the 14,000 descendants of King David. What would have taken years took us seven weeks."

nytimes_articles.abstract: The Frozen Republic How the Constitution Is Paralyzing Democracy. By Daniel Lazare. 393 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $25.    EXCEPTING only a private fortune in excess of $5 billion, nothing in the temple of the American civil religion is more precious than the Constitution brought forth by the corporate sponsors of liberty in Philadelphia in the summer of 1787. In "The Frozen Republic," Daniel Lazare, an accomplished iconoclast, manages within the space of a relatively brief polemic to assign the four pages  of parchment to the realm of magical objects in which a museum of natural history might also place the totem poles and the bones of a departed saint.

Anonymous? Not Me.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
If you didn't write 'Primary Colors,' then why are you denying it on TV so much?" is the most frequently asked question in Washington these days. This is the new novel whose plot distinctly resembles the 1992 Clinton campaign. The book was signed Anonymous, the author with the very, very airbrushed jacket photo. 

     A few suspects are easily ruled out. George Stephanopoulos, the model for the narrator, has spent too much of his life instructing people where to put the o's and u's in his own last name for him to pick a hard-to-spell pen name like "Anonymous." James Carville and Mary Matalin would have included cute back and forth sparring. Paul Begala is anonymous to most people, so that's a giveaway. Chelsea Clinton has too much homework. Salman Rushdie likes to be on television  too much to write a book sub rosa. J. Edgar Hoover is dead.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
Depending on the time of day, the Village Coffee Company can be many things to many people. Morning commuters charging up the hill to the Maplewood train station stop for a bagel and coffee. After dinner or a movie, it's a good place  for cappuccino and dessert from the impossibly large pastry selection that jams  two glass cases at the front of the store. And for a 2-year-old who's spent a blustery afternoon at Memorial park, it's the place to go for hot chocolate. 

     This is no gritty hot chocolate from a machine. The Village Coffee Company steams milk its big brass-and-copper espresso machine, adds a good squirt of chocolate syrup, and tops it with milk foam, for a comforting drink that warms you from the inside.

IN BRIEF;Legislator Seeks Limit On Bank Account Fees
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Fed up with bank fees on customers who inquire about account balances, State  Senator Louis Kosco, Republican of Paramus, hopes to give consumers a break. He  plans to introduce a bill that would direct the state Division of Consumer Affairs to investigate whether such charges are necessary at all and, if so, to  set maximum rates. 

     "I don't think it's reasonable to charge people who want to find out how much money they have in their accounts," he said. "These are services the banks should absorb."

LIVES;Nana and the Anchormen
Backtalk;Life at the Top: Jerry Bailey Reflects on Cigar
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Cigar, who went 10 for 10 at the races last year to establish himself as the  obvious horse of the year and the best horse of the decade, will begin his 1996  campaign next Saturday in the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park in Florida. When  he became a star last year, Cigar was already 5 years old. Now he's 6, and trying to do it again, with some expert guidance from his jockey, Jerry Bailey.  

     The 38-year-old Bailey is a star in his own right. He was inducted into the Racing Hall of Fame last year and also received the Eclipse Award as 1995's top  jockey. He has been riding Thoroughbreds for two decades, long enough, as he makes clear in this article, to appreciate the once-in-a-lifetime experience that Cigar represents.

SOAPBOX: Maestro, and More;Remembering Henry Lewis, Alight With Intensity
nytimes_articles.abstract:
YOU did not have to be a musician to enjoy Henry Lewis. The former conductor  of the New Jersey Symphony, who died last weekend at 63, was not bound by the treble and bass clefs; his interests overflowed the scale, and he brought a magnificent intensity to everything he did. Which is also to say that his unrelenting enthusiasm could drive you crazy. 

     Henry loved movies, all kinds, from Jean Cocteau's classic "Orpheus" to Steven Spielberg's "Close Encounters of the Third Kind." But you could not simply watch a movie with him; he had ideas about them. Ninety minutes of any film, good or bad, would draw forth hours of theorizing. The same held for theater or ballet, ice skating or tennis or football: whatever he watched was grist for his philosophical mill.

Neighborhood Report;After Bagel Factory Shuts, Workers Find New Place to Picket
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A strike by workers at a now-closed Carroll Gardens bagel factory has shifted in scene from Brooklyn to Staten Island amid workers' claims that management dismissed them for union-organizing activities. 

     The Quaker Oats corporation, which bought the manufacturer, Arnold's Bagelicious Bagels, in 1994, had announced that it would close the Carroll Gardens factory at the end of January and move its operations to Staten Island.

Neighborhood Report;Bakery Stays In Jamaica
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The future of the Continental Baking plant and its 450 employees was imperiled last July when Interstate Bakeries Corporation took over the South Jamaica company and decided it had one too many baking facilities in the Northeast. 

     But because of lobbying by the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, officials at Interstate decided instead to close its East Brunswick, N.J., bakery and expand operations at the Jamaica plant, creating 100 more jobs.

THE GREAT OUTDOORS;When It Rains, It Pours: Floods Pit Towns Against Their Water Company
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Late last month, for the fifth time since October, the Pascack Brook overflowed, filling basements, inundating roads and shutting businesses in Hillsdale and Westwood. To make matters worse, the storm caused a power blackout, so residents could not even bail out with conventional pumps. 

     In other places plagued by chronic flooding, like the Delaware and Passaic River watersheds, victims tend to blame the elements. Here, residents and some local officials are furious at their water company.

nytimes_articles.headline: VIEWPOINT;Wrestling the Tax Devil We Know
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TWO hundred twenty years ago, our country went to war in part because of the  unfairness of consumption taxes imposed by Britain upon her colonies. One hundred thirty-seven years later, in 1913, Americans went to the extraordinary length of amending the Constitution to replace domestic consumption taxes with the Federal income tax as the principal source of our nation's revenue. Since then, our income tax system has consistently raised the revenue needed to meet the Government's spending decisions. Through two world wars and a worldwide Depression, the income tax system has proven capable, flexible and dependable. 

     But today a national debate rages over whether we should retain this system or return to a consumption-based tax system. The decision is important and difficult and will affect every citizen and every business in this country.

nytimes_articles.headline: The View From: Westport;Will a Mansion Find a Home Before All the Doorknobs Are Gone?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN word got out that a waterfront mansion was for sale for $1, curiosity seekers began showing up at Lorna Christophersen's estate on Saugatuck Avenue in Westport. "People are taking doorknobs!," Ms. Christophersen exclaimed. "People  are taking knobs off the fireplace! It's unfortunate." 

     The numerous, unannounced visitors were hard to take. "I've had to call the police in the middle of the night to get people off the property," said Ms. Christophersen, who lives in the carriage house on the estate her father purchased in 1951.

THE WORLD;A Duchess: Her Life In Debt
On Internet, Memories Of Herricks
nytimes_articles.abstract:
GRADUATES of Herricks High School don't have to wait 5 or 10 years between reunions, and they don't have to leave their homes as far away as California and Arizona to get there. They've been meeting Sunday nights at 7:30 in a chat room  (keyword: Herricks) on America Online. 

     Each week they reminisce about "the Hill," a steep, wooded slope on school grounds that was a favorite hangout for cutting class or smoking cigarettes. They revisit streets and subdivisions from the school district, whose peculiar geography drew its student body from a half-dozen or so sometimes overlapping suburban locales: Manhasset Hills and Roslyn and Roslyn Heights and Williston Park and Albertson and Searingtown and New Hyde Park.

nytimes_articles.headline: Neighborhood Report;Worst of Times at Park West High
nytimes_articles.abstract:
About noon on Dec. 5, scores of students at Park West High School brawled for an hour with students from the Repertory School, an alternative school in Park West's basement. Chairs flew and table legs were used as weapons. Eight students were arrested. Seven others and a security officer were taken to the emergency room. It was the third major fight in or around Park West, on 50th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues, in six weeks. 

     In an interview last month, the principal, Stephen J. Budihas, characterized  the fights as "three ugly, unfortunate, unrelated incidents." But a recent report by the Board of Education's Office of Special Investigation describes Park West as a failing high school overwhelmed by a racially torn student body,  with students roaming hallways during class time and tensions between teachers and administrators.

Cuttings;Roots: Exploding the Myths and Misconceptions
nytimes_articles.abstract:
They can be rather ugly, mostly invisible, and normal gardeners don't really  understand them; yet, they provide sustenance and support for all plants. Because roots function mostly out of sight, gardeners have conjured up some pretty fanciful assumptions about how they grow. Such misconceptions permeate gardening behavior and have distorted how almost every shade tree and fruit tree in America is watered, mulched and fertilized. Here are some common myths about root growth: 

  MYTH NO. 1: TREE ROOTS ARE AS WIDE AS THE CANOPY.  This old adage is as widespread as it is wrong. In heavy clay soils, which have little air and offer  a lot of resistance to root hairs, tree roots may grow only half again as wide as the canopy, but well beyond its canopy's edge, also called the "dripline." In sandy soils, which offer less physical resistance, roots will often grow up to three times as wide. In a shallow soil on top of a clay or hardpan layer, the roots may wander out to an area five times as wide as the canopy in search of moisture and nutrients.

nytimes_articles.abstract: IT was the time of the month for paperwork. He checked every item on the $650 Visa bill to make sure it was correct. Likewise the phone bill. He even double-checked the deductions on his and his wife's paycheck stubs. Once, he had found an error in the amount withheld for Federal taxes, and it pleased him  that the monthly tedium of checking was worth it. This month, the Federal withholding correctly totaled $833.33.

In the Executive Alphabet, You Call Them C.L.O.'s
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE General Electric manager was dismayed. As he spoke to a recent gathering  of company workers, he displayed a chart showing that sales of appliances had slowed substantially. The appliance division, he and others surmised, appeared to be in serious marketing trouble. 

     But the attendees soon learned that the problem had nothing to do with pricing, advertising or other basic marketing tasks. "Up speaks a GE Capital guy and puts up his chart showing consumer debt reaching saturation levels," said Steven Kerr, vice president of leadership development at G.E.  "Suddenly, everyone had a whole new angle on the problem." That new perspective led the employees to try solutions not from marketing but rather from finance, such as new ways to help debt-laden customers pay for big-ticket appliances.

Neighborhood Report;The Gritty and the Gentry Battle for a Waterfront's Soul
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Pockets of homes dot the industrially dominated streets of western Red Hook,  where ships' men once lived and maritime voyagers slept. Today the link between  home and work is gone: most residents work away from the area and the small-business owners largely live outside the neighborhood. 

     The tension has grown as residents who have moved in over the last five years or so seek to transform the commercial character of the waterfront neighborhood  into a mixed-use enclave. What used to be common practices for the existing manufacturing and trucking businesses are now regarded as intolerable by residents, some of whom have started organized campaigns against the businesses.
